clinical_study.brief_title: Trial of Auto Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP)
clinical_study.official_title: Reliability of Automatic CPAP Devices. A Double Blind Dummy Controlled Phase 1 Study

lead_sponsor.agency: Cliniques universitaires Saint-Luc- Université Catholique de Louvain

clinical_study.source: Cliniques universitaires Saint-Luc- Université Catholique de Louvain

brief_summary.textblock: Background: In patients with obstructive sleep apnea, automatic continuous positive airway pressure machines (autoCPAP) are said to be capable of identifying various breathing abnormalities during sleep and to correct them by increasing progressively the positive pressure applied to the airway. Once breathing becomes normal, pressure slowly declines. AutoCPAP devices have never been tested in Phase I studies. The investigators hypothesised that normal breathing would not be recognised as such, and that pressure would increase even in a normal subject.

detailed_description.textblock: Material and Methods: We will submit one normal (confirmed with two polysomnographies, PSG) subject to a double blind study. Pairs of PSG will be performed on successive days once a week, one night with a 4 cm water fixed pressure CPAP device, previously shown not to disturb the subject's sleep and breathing, the other night with one of five well known autoCPAP devices programmed to work between 4 and 15 cm H2O pressure. The same mask and headgear will be used throughout the study. The subject and the physicians reading the tracings will ignore which device is being used on which night.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: number of episodes of increases in applied positive pressure, duration of each episode, and maximal pressure attained

secondary_outcome.measure: reasons for pressure increase and consequences of the increase on sleep continuity

arm_group.description: subject will sleep with a fixed CPAP device at minimal pressure
the subject will sleep connected to an autoCPAP device

intervention.description: autoCPAP working between 4 and 15 cm H2O

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- normal subject
- male and female
- age 18 to 65 years old
Exclusion Criteria:
- obstructive sleep apnea
- unable to sleep with a CPAP device
